intro: Hey there, young scientists! Let's explore how heat loves to travel. Think of it like a busy path where energy always moves from a warm place to a cooler one. Ready to see this in action?

questions.question: Imagine you have a hot cup of cocoa (object1) and a cold glass of water (object2). If you put them next to each other, which way will the heat energy flow?
options: Heat will flow from the cocoa to the water.
Heat will flow from the water to the cocoa.
Heat will not flow at all.
Heat will flow equally in both directions.
questions.hint: Remember, heat likes to spread out from where it's more concentrated (hotter) to where it's less concentrated (colder).

questions.question: If object1 is at 70°C and object2 is at 20°C, what will happen to their temperatures over time if they are in contact?
options: Object1's temperature will increase and object2's temperature will decrease.
Object1's temperature will decrease and object2's temperature will increase.
Both temperatures will stay the same.
questions.hint: Heat moves from the hotter object to the colder object. What effect does this have on their temperatures?

questions.question: When heat flows from object1 to object2 until they are the same temperature, what is this state called?
questions.hint: Think about when things become balanced or stable.

followups: Great job exploring heat flow! You saw how heat naturally moves from hotter to colder things, like our warm cocoa cooling down and the water warming up.
This movement of heat is super important in so many things around us, from cooking our food to how our planet stays warm!
summary: Heat energy always flows from a hotter object to a colder object until they reach thermal equilibrium, meaning they are the same temperature.
